description: Tessie Prevost was one of the young Black girls who integrated New Orleans public schools in the 1960s after federal courts forced the system to abide by the Brown vs. the Board of Education ruling.
title: Tessie Prevost, pioneer of Deep South school desegregation, dies at 69

description: Judge Joshua Kindred, a Trump appointee, resigned after investigators concluded he sent crude messages to employees, engaged in sexual contact with a former law clerk and lied to colleagues about it.
title: Alaska federal judge resigns after investigators say he created a hostile workplace

description: The 3rd Annual Adaptive Golf Open is underway in Kansas as disabled golfers from 32 states and 11 countries vy for a championship. The field includes A 20 year old Utah golfer, paralyzed from a ski accident, who’s back defending the championship he won last year in the seated impairment category
title: Golfers travel from around the world for 3rd U.S. Adaptive Golf Open

description: Players at the Copa America have been seen exiting team buses with Mate gourds. Part of the point of Yerba Mate is that it's communal -- perfect to be shared with your 10 best friends after a game.
title: Mate's moment at the Copa

description: A federal judge in Alaska resigns after investigators conclude he created a hostile environment for law clerks and had an inappropriate relationship with one of them.
title: Federal judge resigns after investigation uncovers abusive conduct

description: Israel’s military and politicians are divided on whether to strike a ceasefire deal with Hamas. Israeli experts have presented the government with proposals for a postwar Gaza.
title: Israel is divided over next steps in Gaza

description: Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell testified before a Senate committee today. As inflation cools, the central bank is weighing when it's safe to start cutting interest rates.
title: Fed Chair tells Congress lowering interest rates poses "two-sided risks"

description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Paul Begala, former counselor to President Clinton, about the challenge the White House has in controlling the scrutiny surrounding President Biden's ability.
title: What can the White House do to control the narrative around Biden's ability?

description: As quarterfinal are underway, NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with Washington Post Reporter Ava Wallace on the biggest storylines happening at Wimbledon.
title: After a string of upsets, Wimbledon heads into quarterfinals

description: Humans are traveling farther into space than ever before. We look at the physics of launch – how to send something up and how it can come crashing back down.
title: The physics of launching into space -- and crashing back down

description: About 7.7 million Venezuelans have fled to escape poverty and political turmoil -- about one-fifth of the country's population. It's now a potent issue in Venezuela's presidential election.
title: Maduro faces uphill election battle after leading Venezuela into crisis

description: Democrats returned to Washington with no clear consensus on whether President Biden should be the party's nominee for president.
title: Democrats remain split over Biden's future in the party

description: NPR's Juana Summers talks with Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer about her new book True Gretch: What I've Learned About Life, Leadership and Everything in Between.
title: Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer has “complete confidence” in Biden’s candidacy

description:
We hear from an American who moved to Israel before the October 7th attacks and has served in the Israeli army in Gaza. Over a series of conversations with NPR, he wrestles with the war, his role there, and how much more he can give.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates
title: An American Israeli Soldier's Reflections on Gaza

description: Hundreds of Americans continue to die every day from overdoses. More of those deaths now involve stimulants like cocaine and meth mixed with fentanyl. Men of color have been hit particularly hard.
title: Stimulant users caught up in fatal 'fourth wave' of opioid epidemic

description: Palmer Luckey launched his first tech company as a teenager. He sold it to Facebook for $2 billion. Now he's making AI weapons the Pentagon is buying for itself and also sending to Ukraine.
title: He created Oculus headsets as a teenager. Now he makes AI weapons for Ukraine

description: In his career, Johnston has repeatedly portrayed police officers and agents, from Arrested Development to The Sarah Silverman Program and Men in Black II. His actions against police cost him a job.
title: Actor Jay Johnston of 'Bob's Burgers' and other comedies pleads guilty in Jan. 6 case

description: Most states currently don't have age limits for buying zero-proof beverages that look and taste like beer, wine and liquor. But some researchers argue they could be a gateway into drinking for kids.
title: I.D. please. Should kids be able to buy nonalcoholic beer, wine and mocktails?

description: Five years after mass protests disrupted Hong Kong, and were crushed by the government, people who took part are downsizing their dreams and ambitions — but keeping a small flame of hope alive.
title: 5 years ago they protested for freedom in Hong Kong. They want us to remember them

description: The document shows an aggressive legislative agenda that would upend immigration and the economy while not focusing on topics such as abortion.
title: The new GOP platform follows Trump’s lead; how to combine finances with a partner

description: A petition is circulating in Ukraine to erect a statue of late U.S. President Ronald Reagan in the capital Kyiv. This is the second time Parliamentarian Maryan Zablot-shkyy has launched such a drive.
title: Ukrainian parliamentarian wants a statue of Ronald Reagan in Kiev square

description: The RNC's Platform Committee has adopted former President Donald Trump’s platform, a document that leans into his preferred “America First” stances and steers away from traditional GOP social issues.
title: The Republican Party lays out its 2024 policy platform

description: Families of victims of two Boeing 747 Max crashes are asking a judge to reject a plea deal with the plane maker. NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks talks to attorney Paul Cassell, who represents 15 of the families.
title: Families of place crash victims react to Boeing's plea agreement

description: Companies have waged a quiet revolution in package sizing that they use to squeeze more money out of us. But there’s a weapon to help consumers level the playing field: unit prices.
title: How to fight shrinkflation? Pay attention to unit prices at grocery stores

description: Due to the litigious nature of environmental and climate law, legal experts say the next president's judicial appointments might be their most consequential actions on climate over the next five years.
title: Why judicial appointments by the next president are important to climate change law

description: Even after storms lose their hurricane status and head far inland, they can still cause dangerous floods. Storms like Beryl pose risks far from the coast, even in Canada.
title: Far from the ocean, remnants of storms like Beryl can cause severe floods

description: The Louisiana plantation home where one of the largest slave revolts in U.S. history began has Black owners for the first time. They say the 1811 uprising can inspire a new generation to fight racism.
title: Louisiana plantation where historic slave revolt started now under Black ownership

description: A new law opens up outdoor preschools to low income families in Colorado by allowing them to accept state child care subsidies. Advocates say learning outdoors has advantages over indoor classrooms.
title: Colorado is the 2nd state to approve licenses for outdoor preschools

description: Democratic lawmakers are divided over whether President Biden should end his reelection campaign. Biden is adamant that he will continue, but what is he doing to reassure his colleagues?
title: Democrats on Capitol Hill are consumed with questions over President Biden's future

description: A report shows America's poorest counties are having their best economic period in decades. NPR's Steve Inskeep talks to John Lettieri of the Economic Innovation Group, about their study.
title: Will economic improvements in some counties influence voters?

description: Experts say friendships can be good for health. What are the implications if those relationships are fabricated by artificial intelligence?
title: 'Body Electric': If a bot relationship feels real, should we care that it's not?

description: We tag along up with a running club in the Philadelphia for people trying to recover from addiction.
title: In Philadelphia, a run club helps those recovering from addiction find purpose

description: The GOP platform for 2024 is public. NATO countries gather in Washington to mark the alliance's 75 years of history. Transplant surgeons are using a new, controversial procedure to retrieve organs.
title: Moring news brief

description: Most students pursuing medical degrees at Johns Hopkins University will receive free tuition, thanks to a $1 billion gift from businessman Michael Bloomberg's philanthropic organization.
title: Bloomberg gives $1 billion to Hopkins to make tuition free for most medical students

description: The disclosures by Dr. Kevin O'Connor follow public concerns by Democrats about President Biden's fitness for office and a report about a neurologist's visits to the White House.
title: White House physician says visits by neurologist were part of Biden's routine physicals

description: The three were texting each other during a panel discussion on Jewish life on campus last May, mocking and disparaging students’ complaints of antisemitism.
title: 3 Columbia deans ousted for texts that 'touched on ... antisemitic tropes'
